learning_outcomes.description: Explain important considerations for each step in the process of diagnostic clinical reasoning and demonstrate an ability to reflect on thought processes. Apply the theory and practical skills learnt in the programme thus far to clinical scenarios.

Describe technical, ethical, and animal welfare principles associated with production animal and companion animal practice and apply these and reflect on their influence in the context of veterinary examination and decision making.

Describe and demonstrate the safe, systematic performance of a comprehensive physical examination in species commonly encountered in veterinary practice and then use this information in addition to the clinical history to develop a complete problems list.
Describe the principles of surgery as they relate to preparation of the surgeon and the patient and the various aspects of good surgical technique. Competently demonstrate relevant practical skills.
Describe the principles and practice of diagnostic imaging and radiation safety in veterinary practice. Demonstrate knowledge of normal radiographic anatomy.
Describe the principles of triage and the management of emergent conditions for veterinary patients and the techniques necessary for its delivery. Competently demonstrate relevant practical skills.

Explain the principles of anaesthesia as they relate to patient preparation, anaesthetic agent selection, anaesthesia maintenance, and analgesic therapy. Competently demonstrate relevant practical skills.
Discuss the principles of dentistry in small animal practice including preventative dental medicine and prophylaxis in dogs and cats. Competently demonstrate relevant practical skills.
Identify and explain clinical examination techniques relevant to common behavioural problems in small animals.

assessments.task_description:
This examination will assess material from the Clinical Examination lectures for various animal species delivered during Weeks 1–4 of Semester 1. Species covered include: Ruminants – Cattle and sheep, Equine, Dogs, Birds and Exotics

Detailed information about this assessment will be provided in Week 1, and additional content-related guidance will be available on Blackboard. This exam is Inspera based and will have matching, multiple option, drag-and-drop, extended matching, and fill in the blanks questions

The examination will be delivered through Inspera and held in person on the Gatton campus between 28 March 2026 and 18 April 2026.

Further information, including an overview of Inspera functions, practice activities, and support options will be provided on the course Blackboard site.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

This assessment task evaluates students' abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT). Students are advised that the use of AI or MT technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
1. This exam will cover the content from Week 5 onwards which includes:
  2. Diagnostic Imaging
  3. Clinical Reasoning and schemas
  4. Behaviour in small Animal practice
  5. Welfare & Forensics
  6. Live transport and Export of Food Animals

This exam is Inspera based and will have scenario-based questions, short answer questions, matching, multiple option, drag-and-drop, extended matching, and fill in the blanks questions. Specific details about this assessment will be provided in Week 1 of Semester 1.

This examination will be held in-person on Gatton campus.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.assessment_title: Semester 1 - Clinical Examination of Species OSCE
assessments.due_date:
End of Semester Exam Period

6/06/2026 - 20/06/2026

School-based Prac Exam
assessments.task_description:
Students will be examined on clinical examination skills taught and revised during Semester 1 using live animals. The student will be asked to complete a selection of skills from the list of clinical examination skills revised during the practicals in ruminants (cattle and sheep), horses, dogs, and birds/exotics. The exam for each species will run approximately 10 minutes. Performance will be assessed using a marking rubric.  Additional details will be provided on the course Blackboard site closer to the time of the examination..

There are no second attempts at competency on this assessment.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.assessment_title: Semester 2 - Surgery, Anaesthesia, Dentistry, Clinical Reasoning OSCE
assessments.due_date:
Second End of Semester Exam Period

7/11/2026 - 21/11/2026

School-based Prac Exam
assessments.task_description:
1. S2 OSCE – This is practical Exam and will examine the students for skills in:
  2. Surgery – Surgeon and Patient preparation; Ligatures and Knots; bandaging
  3. Anaesthesia
  4. Dentistry
  5. Clinical Reasoning and schemas – Integration


Students will progress through a number of stations. At each station, they will be required to perform tasks and demonstrate skills that have been learned/acquired in surgery, anaesthesia, and dentistry practical classes. Clinical reasoning lectures/tutorials will be examined through viva. Students may also be expected to answer questions related to the task being examined in written or verbal form. Additional information will be provided on the course Blackboard site.

There are no second attempts at competency on this assessment.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

learning_activities.topic:
Clinical examination of species

Lectures will be given on the clinical exam of small animals, ruminants, pigs, horses, birds, reptiles and small mammals.


Learning outcomes: L01, L03, L09
learning_activities.topic_description: Clinical examination of species Lectures will be given on the clinical exam of small animals, ruminants, pigs, horses, birds, reptiles and small mammals.

learning_activities.topic:
Clinical examination of species

Practical classes will be held on the clinical examination of dogs, horses, ruminants, pigs, birds, reptiles and small mammals.

Learning outcomes: L01, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: Clinical examination of species Practical classes will be held on the clinical examination of dogs, horses, ruminants, pigs, birds, reptiles and small mammals.

learning_activities.topic:
Time in clinics

Students will spend 2-4 hours in clinics with a 5th year mentor.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Time in clinics Students will spend 2-4 hours in clinics with a 5th year mentor.

learning_activities.topic:
Clinical Reasoning Tutorials

Students will work through the diagnostic clinical reasoning process in a series of tutorials.

Learning outcomes: L01
learning_activities.topic_description: Clinical Reasoning Tutorials Students will work through the diagnostic clinical reasoning process in a series of tutorials.

learning_activities.topic:
Triage and Management of Emergencies

Principles of emergency management of veterinary species including topics such as trauma, haemostasis, bandaging, and patient stabilisation.

Learning outcomes: L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Triage and Management of Emergencies Principles of emergency management of veterinary species including topics such as trauma, haemostasis, bandaging, and patient stabilisation.

learning_activities.topic:
Diagnostic clinical reasoning

This series of lectures will cover the considerations necessary at each step in the clinical reasoning process.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02
learning_activities.topic_description: Diagnostic clinical reasoning This series of lectures will cover the considerations necessary at each step in the clinical reasoning process.

Radiology/ radiography principles

A series of lectures on surgical principles such as surgeon and patient preparation, suture materials and suture patterns, and perioperative patient management.

learning_activities.topic:
Surgical principles

Practicals relating to the lecture content. To include skills such as suturing, surgeon preparation, and selection of appropriate suture and suture patterns.

Learning outcomes: L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Surgical principles Practicals relating to the lecture content. To include skills such as suturing, surgeon preparation, and selection of appropriate suture and suture patterns.

Animal welfare

Lectures on welfare assessment and decision making.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02
